title: 803-B
statement: B. Distances to Zerotime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutYou are given the array of integer numbersa0,a1, ...,an- 1. For each element find the distance to the nearest zero (to the element which equals to zero). There is at least one zero element in the given array.InputThe first line contains integern(1 ≤n≤ 2·105) — length of the arraya. The second line contains integer elements of the array separated by single spaces (- 109≤ai≤ 109).OutputPrint the sequenced0,d1, ...,dn- 1, wherediis the difference of indices betweeniand nearestjsuch thataj= 0. It is possible thati=j.ExamplesInput92 1 0 3 0 0 3 2 4Output2 1 0 1 0 0 1 2 3Input50 1 2 3 4Output0 1 2 3 4Input75 6 0 1 -2 3 4Output2 1 0 1 2 3 4

processed.result:
You are given an array of integers.  For each number in the array, find the distance to the nearest zero. The distance is the difference between the index of the number and the index of the nearest zero. If a number is zero, the distance is 0.

**Example:**

Input array: [2, 1, 0, 3, 0, 0, 3, 2, 4]

Output array: [2, 1, 0, 1, 0, 0, 1, 2, 3]
Given a list of numbers, find the distance to the nearest zero for each number in the list. The distance is the difference in position between the number and the nearest zero.
